results.title: Pottery ladies. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Arts Council of Great Britain, Elizabeth Taylor-Mead and Jenny Wilkes
results.brief_description: Colin Melbourne (former head of Burslem Art School), Peggy Davies (pottery sculptor) and Gordon Elliot (ceramic historian) discuss the relationship between the Burslem Art School and the pottery industry and the influences on the works of the designers Susie Cooper, Charlotte Rhead and Clarice Cliff.

results.title: Pottery ladies. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Arts Council of Great Britain, Elizabeth Taylor-Mead and Jenny Wilkes
results.brief_description: Joan Jackson (Rhead’s biographer), Gordon Elliot (ceramic historian), Barry Leigh (manufacturer) and the women employed in the manufacturing process of Rhead’s work discuss and trace the history, influences and production techniques of Charlotte Rhead’s work.

results.title: Potters of Hebron
results.brief_description: Looks at a Middle Eastern family of potters who make water pitchers and other utensils for local consumption. The traditional techniques shown include finding the source of clay, preparation, wedging, throwing, firing and the kick wheel.

results.title: Potter: Robin Welch
results.brief_description: Robin Welch, a potter from Great Britain, was Artist-in-Residence at Gippsland Institute of Advanced Education. His work is thrown, but stretches wheel concepts to extremes with delicate, torn edges and painterly attitudes to glaze.
results.description: Robin Welch, a potter from Great Britain, was Artist-in-Residence at Gippsland Institute of Advanced Education. His work is thrown, but stretches wheel concepts to extremes with delicate, torn edges and painterly attitudes to glaze.

results.title: Potter's Song: Art and philosophy of Paul Soldner
results.creator_credit: Crystal Productions, Dick Hoffman, Tom Hubbard and David Hubbard
results.brief_description: Explains the work and philosophy of ceramic artist and educator, Paul Soldner. Shows him demonstrating his techniques he has developed to create his non-functional raku pottery, and discussing the changing course of his ceramic art and its relationship to the environment.

results.title: Potomok Chingis-Khana = Storm over Asia
results.brief_description:
Set during the British occupation of Mongolia in 1920, this is the half heroic, half ironic story of Bair, a young Mongolian hunter-turned-partisan who is captured. A document in his possession identifies him as a descendent of Genghis Khan. The interventionists decide to ‘resurrect’ him as a puppet king. However Bair escapes and leads the Mongolian army against the interventionists. The intensity of the drama, strong feeling for landscape and dramatic use of montage (4 or 5 times the usual number of shots for a feature of this length) have been compared with the work of D. W. Griffith. In effect, the film is one long chase which takes on mythic proportions while the plot takes on metaphoric and lyrical dimensions (the British army is literally ‘blown away’). The emotional impact disguises the methodological rigour of Pudovkin’s construction. Also available on 16mm and VHS.

Credits: Director, producer, Vsevolod Pudovkin ; script, Osip Brik ; photography, Anatoli Golovnya ; music, N. Kryukov.
Cast: Valeri Inkizhinov.

results.title: Potkoorok
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and John Walker
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Nargun and the stars”.
Based on the novel of the same name by Patricia Wrightson, this is the story of Simon Brent, a city boy sent to live with country relatives after the death of his parents. He resents the move to a different lifestyle and is bored with country life until he meets some ancient creatures that have inhabited the area since Dreamtime. In this episode he stumbles upon The Potkoorok, a fierce and loathesome creature.

results.title: Potatoes
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Roman Bittman and Robert Lang
results.brief_description: This documentary deals with the gradual shift from the family farm, to corporation-run farms, with all the ensuring problems and personal hardship. It is an incisive evaluation of what is happening in North America particularly St Johns Valley of New Brunswick and in world wide agriculture today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ONF | NFB, Roman Bittman and Robert Lang

results.title: Potash deficiency
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Tony Doogood
results.brief_description: Potash deficiency occurs in older pastures ad sandy areas in Victoria. The rate of depletion is shown by the fact that 2 and a half tons of hay remove 1 cwt. of potash from the soil. The symptoms of this deficiency in pastures; how to apply potassium fertilizers; pasture management to prevent deficiency; the economics of costs and returns from the use of potassium fertilizers.
